column10: Wild bonobos do use tools, but those are almost exclusively associated with social and self-care activities and not with foraging, which is of special relevance for the the tool use hypothesis of handedness evolution. We therefore categorize bonobos as non-habitual tool users for the context of our analyses. Compare Musgrave, S., & Sanz, C. (2018). Tool use in nonhuman primates. The international encyclopedia of anthropology, 1-7.

column4: Powell, L. E., Isler, K., & Barton, R. A. (2017). Re-evaluating the link between brain size and behavioural ecology in primates. Proceedings of the Royal Society B: Biological Sciences, 284(1865), 20171765.
column6: Powell, L. E., Isler, K., & Barton, R. A. (2017). Re-evaluating the link between brain size and behavioural ecology in primates. Proceedings of the Royal Society B: Biological Sciences, 284(1865), 20171765.
column10: Tool use in wild gorillas has been demonstrated, but is exceedingly rare when compared to other great apes or capuchins. Thus, we do not recognize them as habitual tool users here (see Musgrave, S., & Sanz, C. (2018). Tool use in nonhuman primates. The international encyclopedia of anthropology, 1-7.)
